Aspects of organizing concepts

Categories. As mentioned before, concepts are organized in a hierarchy. In this hierarchy, each concept maintains a String category along with the parent concept. The purpose of the category is to classify the concept's role under the the parent concept. For example, the children of a Contact concept could use categories such as "address", "phone", "website" and so on, to classify the different addresses, phone numbers and websites of a contact.

You can edit the category of a Concept in the “Edit Concept Details” in the Editor. You can also filter concepts by category in the Finder using the “Show all” dropdown button in each panel. The ConceptJS API also supports querying children of a concept by their category.

In this unit, we will create a very simple contacts management app that illustrates three methods to organize concepts. The first method is to automatically rename concepts to provide a textual summary, using the "Named Concept" core concept. The second method is to place concepts inside "Folder" concepts. We will finally change the folder to a user-defined concept that lists various contacts and provides methods to add, modify and delete contacts.

Automatically renaming concepts

"Named Concept" is a core concept that lets you automatically rename a concept based on its properties. You can follow these steps to create a Contact lambda concept and an example contact which automatically renames itself:

  1. Copy-paste the Person lambda-concept at the same level.
  2. Edit the pasted concept and change its name to "Contact".
  3. Add a lambda property called email of type String, and mark it as an "Optional" property defaulting to an empty string.
  4. Select the htmlTemplate property and edit its contents to add an input field for email, after the last name, as follows: 
      <div class="form-group">
    <label for="inputEmail" class="col-sm-2 control-label">Email</label>
    <div class="col-sm-10">
      <input type="email" class="form-control" id="inputEmail" placeholder="Enter the email (optional)" data-bind="textInput: email">
    </div>
  </div>
  5. Add a simple property called namedConcept set to the concept "Named Concept".
  6. Assign the name of the Named Concept as the following Javascript expression ( ): 
      return firstName + ' ' + lastName + ' (Person)';
  7. Add an is-a relationship to the property namedConcept.
  8. Save the changes made to the "Contact" lambda-concept in the Editor. You now have a reusable lambda-concept called Contact that shows any first name, last name and email in an editable form, and automatically renames itself to the given name.
  9. To test the "Contact", you can add a blank concept under it in the Finder, and set the new concept's name to "Example Contact" in the Editor.
  10. Add a simple property called contact set to the concept "Contact" defined in your repository.
  11. Assign the three bindings of the Contact (firstName, lastName and email) to some initial values or just empty strings. You can edit them in the Viewer as well.
  12. Add an is-a relationship in the "Example Contact" concept to its property contact.
  13. Open the "Example Contact" in the Viewer to enter your contact information, and save the changes using the form's Save button.
  14. When you refresh the "Example Contact" in the Editor, you will see the changes made to the contact property's bindings.
  15. When you refresh the "Example Contact" in the Finder, you will see that it has been automatically renamed to your name followed by the string "(Person)".

Putting concepts in a Folder

ConceptJS includes a user-defined lambda concept called "Folder". The Folder concept provides an easy way to navigate multiple concepts without using the IDE.

You can follow these steps to manage contacts inside a folder:

  1. Open the "Contact" lambda concept in the IDE.
  2. Select the "Contact" concept in the Finder and click the Add button in the panel to its right to create a "New Folder". The folder will be visible in the Viewer.
  3. Change the name of the folder in the Viewer from "Untitled" to "Contacts List".
  4. Double-click the description to change it to something like "This folder maintains a list of sample contacts".
  5. Save the changes in the Viewer.
  6. Cut-paste the example contact from the previous exercise as a child of the folder. You can also use drag-and-drop as shown in the video at 0:30.
  7. You can also copy-paste "Example Contact" to create more contacts based.
  8. Refresh the folder in the viewer to see the child concepts. You can also view the folder in presentation mode.
  9. Check out the find and sort features in the folder.

Creating a Contact List page

The following video shows how you can adapt code from a lambda-concept used by "Folder" called "HTML Page with Children", and create a custom folder concept.

You can follow these instructions to copy the folder:

  1. Click Custom Contact Folder to view the custom contact folder in the IDE mode.
  2. Open the Finder to view the "Custom Contact Folder" concept built by the conceptjs user.
  3. Copy the "Custom Contact Folder" to the ConceptJS clipboard.
  4. Click the < button in the Finder till you see "My Repos" listing your repositories.
  5. Select the default repository and the "Contact" concept under it.
  6. Paste the concept from the clipboard to the panel under the "Contact" concept.
  7. Rename the pasted concept to "Custom Contact Folder" in the Editor, and save the changes.
  8. Cut-paste the examples contacts listed under "Contact Folder" as children of your new "Custom Contact Folder".

Recap

  • Concepts that have is-a relationships to "Named Concept" are automatically renamed to the name property provided in its binding.
  • You can use the Finder to add Folder concepts that list children concepts by their name and category.
  • The home.children([optional category]) method returns a list of Concept objects representing the children of the concept. This API can be used by server-side scripts to access properties of the children.
  • You can use the expression $cjs("...simple concept URI...").as("...lambda concept URI...") to find the is-a relationship from the given simple concept to the given lambda concept.
